Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Many studies have focused on developing materials for conventional acoustic applications, such as ultrasound imaging, sound insulation, and geological logging. However, the design of materials that actively respond to sound and concurrently shift their acoustic and optical characteristics remains in its infancy. The goal of this project is to design acoustically responsive materials that alter their chemical structure, physical properties, and object shapes whenever they interact with sound waves enabling active modulation of acoustic properties including speed of sound, attenuation, and phononic band gaps. If compared to electromagnetic radiation, sound waves possess unique physical characteristics as they readily propagate through optically non-transparent materials, including liquids, solids, and gels (e.g., human body), where direct application of conventional stimuli, such as light and electric fields, is either physically or physiologically prohibited. This enables non-invasive interrogation of a wide range of materials properties and remote activation of various mechanochemical processes. Moreover, similar to electromagnetic radiation, sound can be focused both in space and in time. This opens intriguing opportunities to perform local modifications in a time-controlled, sequential manner. These materials may be utilized both in materials engineering for acoustic lithography and self-healing and in biomedical applications including non-invasive surgery, diagnostics, and drug-delivery.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The project goal is to develop a new direction in materials design wherein fundamental changes in materials properties are activated by sound waves that concurrently shift acoustic, optical, and geometric characteristics of macroscopic objects. The research activities pursue three strategic objectives. First, develop fundamental understanding of hierarchic correlations between the multi-scale architecture of complex macromolecules and mechanical properties of materials assembled of these molecular mesoblocks. Theoretical studies will provide guidelines for synthesis of materials with an extraordinarily broad range of elasticity, strength, and toughness that are currently not available in conventional polymer systems. Second, study the interaction of sound waves with stimuli responsive polymer systems and explore different activation mechanisms that shift density, modulus, compressibility, and shape. Understanding the feedback between acoustically triggered changes in materials properties and the corresponding shifts in acoustic characteristics represents an intellectual challenge of this proposal. Third, create a novel class of materials that can be activated, actuated, and navigated remotely using acoustic fields in a programmable and time-resolved manner. An anticipated culmination of this project is acoustically transformative materials that not only respond to sound but also fundamentally change their physical properties, object dimensions, and acoustic and optical characteristics. The collaborative nature of this project will ensure interdisciplinary training of junior researchers in polymer synthesis, physical experiments, and theory. The project also provides opportunity for broadening participation of underrepresented groups and fostering infrastructure for collaborative research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this proposal was to create novel class of acoustically responsive materials that can be activated, actuated, and navigated remotely in a programmable and time-resolved manner. Theoretical predictions guided synthesis of novel polymeric architectures with tissue-mimetic elasticity and softness without adding solvent. Particularly challenging was the feedback between the network architecture, mechanical properties and acoustic response. By understanding these correlations, stimuli-responsive materials were developed that would not only respond to sound by changing their physical properties (density, shear modulus, and shape), but also actively managed acoustic performances, such as tunable phononic band gaps and sound attenuation. 

 The intellectual merit included several strategic objectives: First was to develop fundamental understanding of hierarchic correlations between the multi-scale architecture of brush-like macromolecules and mechanical properties of materials assembled from these molecular meso-blocks. This provided theoretical guidelines for the synthetic design of tissue-mimetic materials with an extraordinary combination of elasticity, stiffness, and toughness that are currently not available in conventional polymer systems. The other goal was to study interaction of sound waves with stimuli responsive polymer systems to explore different activation mechanisms that shift density, modulus, and shape. The third objective was to create novel class of materials that can be activated, actuated, and navigated remotely in a programmable and time-resolved manner. The concept of “elastomer genome” was developed based on brush-like polymer architecture, permitting precise and predictable control of mechanical properties of elastomers. The developed architectural code allowed for independent control of modulus and extensibility, previously impossible in conventional linear chain elastomers.. This led to solvent-free single-component materials with tissue-like mechanical properties that were used to replicate the mechanical response of assorted biological tissues including lung, artery, and jellyfish. This development may lead to a universal materials design platform that encodes targeted mechanical behavior, ranging from those of soft brain to tough cartilage, via precision engineering of polymer network architecture.

The developed materials design has a broader impact on several disciplines since it addresses challenges in various advanced applications such as soft  robotics, membranes, energy, and biomedicine. This achievement has been enabled through close interaction between the theoretical, synthetic, and experimental groups participating in the project. For example, the new synthetic advances developed by the CMU group, were then adapted and tuned by the UNC group for specific types of chemical compositions. For the design of acoustically responsive capsules, industrial partners were attracted such as Halliburton, which hold significant experience in acoustic contrast agent and encapsulation of various fluids. Excellent lubrication properties of molecular brushes have been explored in wear protection models of cartilage. The project involved education of graduate, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. They were exposed to the most recent and advanced synthetic techniques, characterization of polymeric materials and modeling their properties. They presented at national and international symposia as well as at semiannual Consortium meetings at CMU. They started successful careers in either academia or industry. PI research was recognized by several international and national awards including Franklin Medal in Chemistry (2017) and The Dreyfus Prize in Chemical Sciences (2015). The ACS Meeting on Controlled Radical Polymerization was organized in 2017 with ca. 90 oral and 90 poster presentations.  Controlled radical polymerization used for synthesis of the new materials is of significant commercial interest as evidenced by 56 international companies that have participated at the industrial consortium at Carnegie Mellon and 16 signed licenses resulting in new products commercialized in US, Europe and Japan.
